page.title: 14Water Problems
page.content: Acid rain is becoming an increasing problem in our area. It is caused by fumes from motor vehicles and industrial smoke which enters the atmosphere, turning the rain acid. The acid is killing off 10% of fish every year. Galloway is one of the most severely affected areas in the world. Another problem is silage effluent from silage pits. This is the juice from the grass which seeps out and finds its way to the river; this kills the food for fish, causing their death. In the past two years there has been a serious problem with drought. Last year use of water was restricted with threat of water rationing. Springholm burn stopped flowing altogether. The waterfall at Spottes Glen was reduced to a trickle. Rivers had to be closed to fishers.
